PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

 

   

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up  to  $176,700,000,  comprising  (i)  an  A  loan  of  up  to  $27,900,000;  and  (ii)  a  B  loan  of  up  to 
$148,800,000 to Phu Yen TTP Joint Stock Company (Phu Yen JSC) for the B.Grimm Viet Nam 
Solar  Power  Project  (Phu  Yen  Project)  in  Viet  Nam.  The  report  also  describes  the  proposed 
administration  of  a  loan  of  up  to  $9,300,000  to  be  provided  by  the  Leading  Asia’s  Private 
Infrastructure Fund (LEAP)1. If the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the LEAP loan. 
 
2. 
The loan will support Phu Yen JSC to operate a 257-megawatt (MW) solar photovoltaic 
power plant and its associated facilities in Phu Yen Province, Viet Nam. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) financing will meet the borrower’s requirements for longer-tenor United States (US) 
dollar-denominated project financing, which local financial institutions are unable to provide. The 
financing  will  also  catalyze  commercial  cofinancing  for  one  of  the  largest  scale  solar  power 
projects in Southeast Asia. In addition, ADB’s participation in the project will ensure compliance 
with  rigorous  environmental  and  social  safeguard  standards,  and  will  enable  gender  design 
features and targets to be incorporated. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT  

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

3. 
Project identification. High rates of economic growth, industrialization, and urbanization 
are  leading  to  growing  electricity  demand  in  Viet  Nam,  which  has  become  the  second-largest 
power market in Southeast Asia (after Indonesia). Access to electricity, which was less than 10% 
of the population in 1986, is now nearly universal (99.5% in 2019). Electricity demand has grown 
rapidly, averaging 12.0% per year from 2005 to 2018, and is projected to grow at more than 8.0% 
per  year through  2030. However, meeting  fast-growing  electricity  demand  and  sustaining  high 
rates of economic growth will be a significant challenge for Viet Nam. According to the Revised 
National Power Development Master Plan, 2011–2020 (PDP VII), Viet Nam needs to invest about 
$148 billion in power transmission and generation infrastructure from 2016 to 2030.2 Because of 
financial  constraints  on  the  state  utility  Vietnam  Electricity  (EVN)  and  limits  on  sovereign 
borrowing, private sector investment will be essential to avoid future power shortages. 
  
4. 
In 2018, large hydropower, coal, and gas projects comprised nearly 90% of Viet Nam’s 
54.9 gigawatts (GW) of installed power capacity. With limited potential remaining to develop large-
scale  hydropower  plants,  depleting  domestic  coal  reserves,  and  growing  public  concern  over 
environmental issues, renewable energy development is receiving greater focus. Viet Nam’s PDP 
VII seeks to increase the share of renewable energy as a percentage of total forecast installed 
capacity to 21% (27 GW) by 2030 and to reduce the use of imported coal-fired electricity. To meet 
this target, installed solar power capacity is expected to increase to 12 GW by 2030.  
 
5. 
In  April  2017,  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  issued  a  decision  to  accelerate  the 
development of private sector solar projects. This decision included a provision for a 20-year feed-
in tariff (FIT) of $0.0935 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) for utility-scale solar power projects. Although the 
new FIT policy sparked significant private sector interest, project developers and financiers faced 
two  major  challenges.  First,  developers  wishing  to  receive  the  FIT  were  required  to  be 

1   Financing partner: Japan International Cooperation Agency. 
2  Vietnam Electricity. 2016. Revised National Power Development Master Plan 2011–2020. Ha Noi. 

 

 2 

commissioned  by  the  end  of  June  2019—a  compressed  development  and  construction  time 
frame. Second, they were required to use the standard power purchase agreement (PPA) issued 
by the Ministry of Industry and Trade, which is not considered bankable for international lenders 
on  a  nonrecourse  project  finance  basis  due  to  its  lack  of  sufficient  protection  for  curtailment, 
changes in law, and various termination scenarios. As a result, developers were unable to obtain 
long-term project financing under these conditions. 
 
6. 
Consequently,  developers  decided  to  proceed  with  project  construction  using  a 
combination of sponsor equity, short-term supplier credit, or corporate loans with short tenors and 
in local currency (dong). This was considered an interim arrangement for many developers, and 
experienced  international  developers  such  as  B.Grimm  Power  Public  Company  Limited 
(B.Grimm) continued their efforts to structure more sustainable long-term financing solutions. 
 
7. 
By  June  2019,  82  solar  power  plants,  with  a  total  capacity  of  nearly  4.5  GW,  were 
commissioned and connected to the national grid, taking the share of solar power in the country’s 
power mix from less than 0.5% to almost 10.0% in just a few months. This exceeds the target of 
850 MW of solar power by 2020 and 4,000 MW by 2025 set out in PDP VII, but is still below the 
2030 target of 12 GW. However, while the rapid development of solar power capacity is a great 
success in terms of renewable energy development, the need for sustainable financing solutions 
remains of paramount importance to support the sector’s long-term viability and stability. Further, 
rapid development has resulted in network congestion in some areas, and certain projects have 
curtailment issues because of grid capacity constraints. 
 
8. 
Since 2018, ADB has engaged in discussions with project developers to explore options 
for financing solutions. Establishing a viable long-term financing structure is critical to support the 
sustainable development of Viet Nam’s renewable energy sector. The ADB approach has been 
to  (i)  selectively  support  high-quality  landmark  projects  developed  by  reputable  sponsors,  and    
(ii) take the lead in developing a bankable structure to help catalyze commercial bank cofinancing 
to Viet Nam’s renewable energy sector by reducing the market perception that long-term financing 
is not feasible. In late 2018, B.Grimm approached ADB to discuss its development pipeline in Viet 
Nam and potential financing structures.3 The projects were considered suitable because of their 
size and strategic location,4 and B.Grimm’s strong technical capacity and record as a developer. 
  
9. 
In response to market conditions and sponsor demand, ADB has developed an innovative 
project finance solution with tailor-made sponsor support to address the key risks in Viet Nam’s 
standard  PPA.  ADB’s  involvement  in  this  project  will  showcase  one  of  the  first  international 
limited-recourse  financings  for  one  of  the  biggest  solar  power  projects  in  the  country  (and  in 
Southeast  Asia).  Through  its  B  loan,  ADB  will  also  mobilize  one  of  the  largest  commercial 
cofinancings for a renewable energy project to date in Viet Nam. ADB has led the deal structuring 
and will ensure compliance with rigorous environmental and social safeguard standards. 
 
10. 
Project design. The project consists of the development and operation of a 257 MW solar 
photovoltaic  power  plant  and  its  associated  facilities  in  Phu  Yen  Province.  The  project  is 
connected to the national grid and has entered into a 20-year PPA with EVN. It will directly serve 
the  electricity  demand  of  Quang  Ngai  and  Nha  Trang  city  and  surrounding  areas—a  region 
emerging as one of Viet Nam’s key tourist centers where power shortages are likely because of

11. 
Borrower  and  sponsors.  The  borrower,  Phu  Yen  JSC,  was  established  in  2016  to 
develop and operate the project. B.Grimm owns 80% of the borrower while Truong Thanh Viet 
Nam Group Joint Stock Company (TTVN) owns the remaining 20%. 
 
12. 
B.Grimm, established in 1993, is one of the largest private power generation companies 
among  Thailand’s  small  power  producer  operators.  As  of  November  2019,  B.Grimm  had  total 
generating  capacity  of  2.9 GW  from  a  diversified  portfolio  including  17  gas-fired  co-generation 
plants, 24 solar power plants, and three hydropower plants. As of November 2019, the company 
had 19 power projects under construction and development, which will raise its total generating 
portfolio  to  3,424  MW  by  2025.  B.Grimm  has  also  established  climate  targets  to  increase  the 
share of renewable energy as a percentage of installed capacity in its portfolio from 8% in 2017 
to 30% in 2022. B.Grimm is one of ADB’s largest private sector clients in Thailand; ADB owns 
4.7% shares and, with ADB assistance, it issued Thailand’s first certified climate bond in 2019.5 
 
13. 
TTVN is a Vietnamese company established in 2012 that is primarily active in real estate 
development,  with  investments  in  luxury  resorts,  commercial  property,  and  social  housing

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs  

15. 
Impact.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  (i)  the  proportion  of  power 
produced from renewable energy sources in the power generation mix in Viet Nam increased by 
2020 (footnote 2), and (ii) emission intensity per unit of gross domestic product reduced.7 
 
16. 
Outcome.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  renewable  power  sustainably 
delivered to the domestic grid increased.8 It will generate 320 gigawatt-hours of electricity from 
solar energy per year and avoid the emission of 123,000 tons of carbon dioxide annually by 2020. 
It will provide at least 15 technical and 200 part-time jobs during the operation phase, and three 
technical or supervisory jobs for women by 2025. 
  
17. 
Outputs. The outputs of the project are that (i) 257 MW solar photovoltaic power project 
and its associated facilities are operational, (ii) gender-responsive human resources policy and 
practices are established, and (iii) employment opportunities for women are increased.

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

18. 
Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s  Strategy  2030,  which  outlines  seven  operational  priorities  to  address  development 
challenges in Asia and the Pacific.9 It supports two of those priorities: (i) tackling climate change, 
building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability;  and 
(ii) addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing  inequality.  It  also  supports  Strategy  2030’s 
objectives to expand the role of private sector operations and mobilize additional resources on 
top of ADB’s own financing. 
 
19. 
ADB has long-standing, strong, and successful cooperation with Viet Nam. The project is 
aligned with two of the three pillars of the country partnership strategy for Viet Nam, 2016–2020: 
(i)  increasing  the  inclusiveness  of  infrastructure  and  service  delivery  and  (ii)  improving 
environmental  sustainability  and  climate  change  response. 10 The  project  is  also  aligned  with 
Viet Nam’s  commitments  to  the  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate  Change, 
targeting a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions of 8%–25% by 2030 (footnote 7). 
 
20. 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  project  aligns 
with ADB’s Energy Policy, which supports wider access to energy through investments in energy 
efficiency and renewable energy projects.11 It will contribute to ADB’s target of $6 billion in annual 
financing for climate mitigation and adaptation by 2020. Consistent with a “One ADB” approach, 
the  project  benefitted  from  close  cross-departmental  coordination  with  ADB’s  Southeast  Asia 
Department in assessing and analyzing Viet Nam’s energy sector.

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

 
22. 
ADB’s assistance will have three components: (i) a direct senior secured loan, A loan, of 
up  to  $27,900,000;  (ii)  a  B  loan  of  up  to  $148,800,000  to  be  funded  by  participating  financial 
institutions;  and  (iii)  administration  of  a  parallel  senior  secured  loan  of  up  to  $9,300,000  to  be 
provided  by  LEAP.  The  A  loan  will  be  provided  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources.  
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

23. 
ADB adds value by mobilizing a financing package that makes the project commercially 
viable. International lenders are not comfortable offering long-term US dollar-denominated debt 
on a nonrecourse basis in the Vietnamese renewables market because of concerns regarding the 
PPA  and  the  nascency  of  the  sector.  Local  banks  are  unable  to  offer  US  dollar-denominated 
longer  tenor  debt.  As  one  of the first  and  biggest  international  limited-recourse  project finance 
transactions in Viet Nam’s renewable energy sector, the project will demonstrate the potential for 
private  sector  investment  in  the  sector,  send  a  strong  signal  to  the  market,  and  attract  other 
investors for similar investments. ADB has led the structuring of the transaction and is crowding 
in commercial banks under the B loan structure, at a cofinancing ratio of $5.3 for every $1 of ADB 
assistance. ADB will offer a longer tenor than participating commercial banks, helping to improve 

 

 6 

debt service coverage ratios for lenders and thereby improve the project’s financial viability. 
 
24. 
ADB’s  support  for  the  project  will  demonstrate  that  innovative  financing  solutions  can 
address existing challenges in this nascent market. The support also contributes to B.Grimm’s 
target of increasing the share of renewable energy in its portfolio. ADB’s involvement and due 
diligence  will  ensure  that  the  project  is  developed  and  operated  to  international  best  practice 
standards and will perform to expectations over the project life. ADB’s participation in the project 
will enable gender design features and targets to be incorporated, and will also ensure compliance 
with ADB’s rigorous environmental and social safeguard standards.

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

25. 
ADB has categorized the project in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009)  as  follows:  environment  (category  B),  involuntary  resettlement  (category  B),  and 
indigenous peoples (category B). Safeguard Requirement 4 for existing facilities is applicable.15 
  
26. 
ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, and mitigate for the adverse impacts 
in the safeguard reports and plans. An environmental and social compliance audit was conducted 
in  parallel  by  an  independent  consultant  to  assess  the  project’s  performance  against  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  requirements.  The  environmental  and  social  measures  and  the 
institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  Phu  Yen  JSC  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and 
environmental  impacts  are  required  to  be  enhanced  to  ensure  the  ongoing  management  of 
safeguards aspects in compliance with ADB SPS requirements. 
 
27. 
Environment.  The  project’s  environmental  impact  assessment  report  was  prepared  in 
compliance  with  Vietnamese  regulations  and  approved  by  the  chair  of  the  Provincial  People’s 
Committee in July 2018. The project area has moderately flat plain and semi-mountainous terrain. 
The project, including the transmission line right-of-way, is not located within or adjacent to any 
environmentally  sensitive  area.  It  retained  the  original  state  of  undulating  areas  and  streams 
running across the site, and did not undertake any ground leveling. The project considered 100-
year  floods  in  its  drainage  system  design.  The  independent  audit  observed  gaps  in  the 
environment,  health,  and  safety  performance,  including  (i)  the  absence of  a  designated  safety 
officer; (ii) unsafe practices, such as working at heights without proper protection; (iii) improper 
waste handling, management, and disposal; (iv) poor housekeeping practices (e.g., waste and 
trash resulting in partial clogging of drains); and (v) inadequate traffic and security management. 
The audit also noted the lack of a formal grievance redress mechanism for internal and external 
stakeholders.  Phu  Yen  JSC  has  agreed  to  implement  corrective  actions  to  address  the  gaps 
before  the  loan  drawdown.  During  operation,  the  borrower  will  prepare  an  operational 
environmental  and  social  management  plan  that  will  include  mitigation,  monitoring,  and 
management measures for waste handling, pollution prevention, grievances, health, and safety 
procedures. It will also work on measures to avoid flooding during typhoon seasons.

256 ha to the project for 50 years through the land use rights certificate awarded on 21 June 2019 
and valid until 5 May 2068. Aside from this, the project directly purchased about 6 ha of land on 
a willing seller–willing buyer basis. These have been done in accordance with the expectations of 
the  affected  land  users.  Before  the  resumption  of  land  rights  (undertaken  before  ADB’s 
involvement) by the government and the subsequent transfer to the borrower, the land was used 
for varied agricultural purposes (mostly plantation and single cropping of cassava and sugarcane). 
However, the affected land users did not rely heavily on the land for their sustenance or livelihood, 
since  it  was  not  suitable  for  intensive  agriculture  or  plantation  because  of  poor  soil  quality.  A 
portion of the farmland was also communally owned and included (i) undulating areas and small 
streams  running  across  the  site,  (ii)  internal  access  roads,  and  (iii) graveyards  for  ethnic 
minorities—the Cham Hoi Roi. Although the affected people were not solely dependent on this 
land  for  their  livelihoods,  the  project’s  land  acquisition  caused  loss  of  or  disruption  to  the 
livelihoods of nearly 166 households (approximatively 650 persons). The land transfer and lease 
also  impacted  the  community  graves  of  the  ethnic  minorities  (16  households  comprised  of 
approximatively  64 persons).  In  addition,  it  disrupted  community  access to  areas  adjoining  the 
solar farm. 
 
29. 
An  independent  third  party  undertook  an  audit  of  the  land  transfer  and  its  impact  on  
existing users. The audit findings suggest that (i) the resumption and transfer of land rights was 
done in accordance with statutory requirements, (ii) all affected households were compensated 
for    loss  of  income  resulting  from  loss  of  land  and  other  productive  assets,  (iii)   no  legacy  or 
ongoing  encumbrances  or  risks  are  associated  with  project  lands,  and  (iv) the  land  and  asset 
compensation  process  provided  enhanced  compensation  and  other  benefits  that  exceed  
statutory  requirements  and  were  largely  aligned  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
requirements. To support their transition, 118 of the 166 affected households or approximately 
472 persons were given additional allowances (in the form of compensation and optional training). 
 
As  mitigation  measures  for  potential  residual  impacts  and  in  accordance  with  the  audit 
30. 
recommendation, a livelihood restoration plan (LRP) will be prepared and implemented for the 
affected,  vulnerable,  willing  and  suitable  families,  and  a  project  level  grievance  redress 
mechanism will be developed to receive and address potential concerns of the project-affected 
people by Phu Yen JSC before the first loan disbursement. The LRP will build on the livelihood 
support  already  provided  to  affected  households  to  address  the  long-term  impact  of  land  and 
livelihood  losses.  The  LRP  will  include  an  assessment  of  affected  households’  socioeconomic 
condition and the provision of opportunities for skills building and alternative livelihoods to ensure 
the restoration of sustenance and livelihood status to at least pre-project levels. 
 
31. 
The land acquisition included a communal lot used as a graveyard of the Cham Hoi Roi 
ethnic group. A total of 18 graves owned by 16 Cham households were transferred to adjoining 
land parcels next to the site boundary. The audit confirmed that the graveyard was relocated in 
accordance with the sociocultural norms and practices of the Cham people. Land for relocation 
(including additional land for future use) has been allocated to the ethnic community. Extensive 
and culturally oriented engagements (meaningful consultations) with the ethnic group (including 
all affected households) were undertaken by the project team; and compensation rates, timelines, 
and  the  process  of  grave  relocation  were  mutually  agreed  through  these  engagements. 
Representatives from the village level commune, the tribal chieftain, tribal mayor, and affected 
households  expressed  satisfaction  with  the  compensation  and  relocation  process  and  the 
customary  and  cultural  sensitivities  shown  by  the  project.  The  project  has  made  additional 
commitments, including the fencing of the new gravesite, construction of a road, and a bridge for 
easy access to the community graves, which are being implemented. The project will (i) continue 

 

 8 

to  engage  with  the  ethnic  group  in  a  culturally  appropriate  manner,  and  (ii) provide  economic 
opportunities  (as  part  of  the  larger  livelihood  restoration  measures)  for  socioeconomic 
development to willing and qualified households of this group of ethnic minorities. 
 
Effective Gender Mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
32. 
(1998),  Phu  Yen  JSC  has  incorporated  measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and  women’s 
empowerment  in  its  business  activities.  Key features  of  the  gender  action  plan  are  as follows:      
(i) an increase in the proportion of women employed by the borrower in technical and supervisory 
roles; (ii) gender equality for jobs in maintenance and cleaning; (iii) an annual internship program 
for  female  students;  and  (iv) strengthening  of  the  borrower’s  human  resources  policies  and 
procedures  regarding  equal  pay,  a  better  workplace  environment,  access  to  social  security 
benefits, and anti-sexual harassment policies and guidelines. Phu Yen JSC will submit periodic 
reports on the implementation of gender measures to ADB.  
 
33. 
Phu Yen JSC will comply with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy  (2001),  will  take  measures  to  comply  with  internationally  recognized  core  labor 
standards.16 Phu Yen JSC will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its contractors’ compliance 
with such laws and (ii) the measures taken. Information disclosure and consultation with affected 
people will follow ADB requirements.17    
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy 

34. 
Phu Yen JSC and the project sponsors were advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best 
international  practice  relating  to  combating  corruption,  money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of 
terrorism.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions 
prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in 
the event of noncompliance.
